Deleted User 11/14/2020 9:29 PM

Deleted User 11/14/2020 10:01 PM
You have chosen to play as an Officer. Both nations begin to spawn and the 10-minute timer starts to count down. The Brunswick Ducal Corps consists of 4 line infantries, 7 riflemen, 3 sappers, 2 officers (including you) and 2 musicians. Your teammates begin to split into three groups. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Follow the group that's heading to the church. [You'll follow 4 riflemen, a line infantry troop and 2 musicians. It might not be a good idea to storm the church since most of the French troops are doing the same.] 2Ô∏è‚É£ Follow the group that's walking to the docks. [You'll follow 2 riflemen, 2 line infantries and a sapper. Should be a lot safer considering the fact that the French team are focusing on holding the church.] 3Ô∏è‚É£ Stay at spawn and build a camp. [You'll stay with 2 sappers, a rifleman, a line infantry troop and an officer at spawn. The sappers will build a base made up of piles of sandbags and barricades.] 4Ô∏è‚É£ Wander off into the swamp alone. [The swamp is a good hiding place. You see 5 of them marching towards the tower, all with their swords out. What should the 3 of you do? 1Ô∏è‚É£ Jump down from the tower and make a run for it. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Stand your ground and fend the French troops off. (edited)

Deleted User 11/23/2020 11:44 PM
You have chosen to stand your ground and fend the French troops off. The 3 of you pull your swords out and prepare for a fight. The French men begin to climb the ladder like hungry zombies. One French troop reaches to the top and swings his sword at you. You parry it with your blade. You then kick him off the tower, causing him to fall to the ground. A sapper emerges next and manages to cut into a line infantry's thigh with his axe. Thankfully, you are able to finish the sapper off before he could land another blow on the line infantry troop. Just then, another sapper arrives and almost hits you on the back. Luckily you dodge his swing just in time. Before he could make another move, you grab him by his uniform and toss him out of the tower. With the help of the two line troops, you were able to fend of all 5 of the French men. You take some time to catch your breath after that intense fight. In the meantime, the three of you plan your next move: 1Ô∏è‚É£ March to the church. [It should be a lot safer now, considering the fact that you've gotten rid of a group of French men.] 2Ô∏è‚É£ Retreat to spawn. [Your team has finished setting up their base there. It's a safer area than the tower.] 3Ô∏è‚É£ Rush to enemy spawn. [They've got a small base set up at spawn. A couple of light infantry troops and a sapper.] 4Ô∏è‚É£ Stay in the tower. [It's too risky to make a move now. You should stay where you are.]

Deleted User 12/3/2020 10:50 PM
You have chosen to shoot him. You aim your pistol at him and pull the trigger. You miss. Oh god, I think you pissed him off. Why is there boss music? The now enraged bugler charges up the ladder with his sword. He pounces on you and attempts to stab you. Fortunately, one of your line infantry troop stops him with a kick to the head. However, that only made him more furious. He shifts his attention to the poor line troop and lands a brutal slice on his neck, instantly killing him. The bugler then proceeds to pin your other line troop against the wall and go berserk. Several cuts and holes were left on the troop's body before you could lock the bugler's arms. Bad idea. This bugler is strong. He manages to lift you on his back and charges backwards, causing you to crash into a stack of crates from behind. He escapes your grip. He turns around and faces you, getting ready to land a stab. Before he could, however, you land a sidekick on his left hip. This gives you enough time to get up and grab ahold of him once more. You proceed to push him out of the tower. Unfortunately, he manages to grab onto the hook that's attached to the pulley in the tower, allowing him to land safely onto the ground. Well you're screwed. Deleted User 12/9/2020 3:33 AM
You have chosen to stop the bugler from entering the tower. Being the absolute dunce you are, you decide to stay in the tower. He starts climbing the outside ladder to get to you, but you push it away before he could make it to the top. The ladder begins to fall and the bugler lands back-first onto the floor. You climb down to the bottom of the tower and barricade the entrance with nearby crates. Although it isn't enough to stop the bugler from breaking in, it'll at least help you stall until the end of the round. Yes, your plan is to round delay. There's 5 minutes left on the clock. Looking at the player list, the Brunswick Ducal Corps are down to 3 soldiers while the French Empire has 6. Things must've gone wrong at the church. Just then you hear a loud boom coming from the door. It seems ike the bugler is trying to pound the door down. The crates seem to be very good at barri- oh god nevermind he broke the door down. You attempt to climb up the ladder but the bugler grabs hold of your leg. He pulls you down and you fall onto the ground. He's got you cornered. He stares at you menacingly with his bloodshot eyes. It's not going to end like this, you say to yourself, as you pull out your pistol and shoot the bugler right on his stom- click ... and you forgot to reload. Amazing. He grabs your neck and lifts you off the ground. He brings you outside before doing a chokeslam, causing you to land hard onto the stone floor. He pulls out his sabre and gets ready to stab you, but you roll out of the way in time. You get up and land a kick on his crotch, immobilizing him. Then, you use all your might to lift the bugler up and suplex him into the water. Finally, that sweat is dead. However, the fight's not over yet. You still have 5 more French men to handle. Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 1/3/2021 5:35 PM
You finished the days long march, and have arrived at your destination. Whilst you set up camp, you take the time to look at a map. Where are you? 1Ô∏è‚É£ Grasslands 2Ô∏è‚É£ Road to Smolensk 3Ô∏è‚É£ Riverside Encampment 4Ô∏è‚É£ La Rothiere

33
73
Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 1/6/2021 8:20 PM
You heave a large sigh realising how far away the nearest town is. Tomorrow's march is no doubt going to be deja vu, so you make your way along the half-built tents. The odd star and speckles of moonlight provide enough light to jog your memory as you walk along the rows. Endless, shadowy grass coalesced into a single blurry mass, like a dark green wave along the horizon. It presented a perfect contrast to the familiar, jagged materials scattered across your plot in such a way that you immediately recognise it. The monotonous task of draping fabric over planks is interrupted by a few disembodied shouts seeming to flow in from all directions. Even over the confusion, muffled cracks can be heard and their accompanying flashes of light seem to illuminate the entire void. You manage to convince yourself that even a few blasts can illuminate such light-starved places, like a lamp in a mineshaft. This newfound courage brings you to your feet and your eyes to the steep hill opposite the camp. Along the crest, hostile skirmishers break the illusion of an endless expanse, but still appear as pebbles breaking mighty rapids. Even through light smoke the bursts of glow emanating from the light muskets clearly unveil colours, undoubtedly belonging to: 1Ô∏è‚É£France (You go Prussia) 2Ô∏è‚É£Prussia (You go France)
398
74
Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 1/13/2021 2:56 PM
The beauty of the lights and small flaming materials shooting out from the pans was inherently beautiful. This facade was broken, however, when a hopefully stray ball struck the tent beside you. Illumination was blocked by leading tents, but the jagged edges around the fabric‚Äôs hole, like that of a piranha's jaws could still be made out. Even through a crude hole, the man inside fumbling with his long clunky gun, no doubt wore a mask of pure fright. The sight sent a wave of realization and uneasiness down your spine like a dam had burst, you were a soldier, not an onlooker, you had to fight. Making sure to keep your head down, the tent's bland, white interior became your only focus. The trusted, straight outline of your weapon was intersected by your curvy hand as you reached for your: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Musket and sword briquette, the tested instruments of a grenadier. (Garde-Regiment Zu Fub ranker) 2Ô∏è‚É£ Faithful hand axe and light musket, the tools of a patriotic frontiersman. (Freikorps ranker) 3Ô∏è‚É£ Lance and intricately woven banner, the flashy kit of a horseman. (Lancer)

281
40
Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 1/17/2021 12:24 PM
Cool, reliable steel greets your palm as you cup the barrel of your respected firearm. Despite the urgency of the situation, you take the time to handle it with affection. The known, worn geometry is mapped out in your head as you glide along its surface. You can still imagine every imperfection and blemish despite the looming shadows. It is still the same faithful gun, as always. At the same time, the hand axe‚Äôs rough handle still glides gracefully as you twirl it about. It makes its way towards your hip as you shift your gaze upwards. A light tapping of hoofs, an unmistakable sound, barely drifts into the tent over the distracting sound of a starting battle. You lose focus on the hand axe letting your free hand gently come to rest on the rear of your musket as you poke your head through the flaps of the tent. The coast seems clear, albeit with the increased prominence of hoofs clinking. Most of your body is out by the time you see any sign of the responsible riders. They are at the foot of the hill, horses still prancing, as a smirk starts to materialise on your face. Our cavalry has come to ride down those light infantry you pridefully decide. The intoxicating feeling of certain victory erodes like a beach as you realise they could be Frenchmen. It is too hard to make out any defining characteristics with your limited knowledge. Something you are certain about, however, is: 1Ô∏è‚É£ You should try and get a better look as you can‚Äôt be too cautious. 2Ô∏è‚É£ You should be ready to fire as you should be ready for anything. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Sleeking into the labyrinth of tents is best in case they are friendly riders.

23
Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 1/22/2021 4:21 AM
Your gun held firm, you methodically advance on the formed cavalry. Creeping down the hill your body mindlessly works to minimise noise. As the wedge of horse and man grows in your vision, you can‚Äôt help but focus on the leading man. A careless and entitled personality can be made out just from his arms elegant motions. The exaggerated movements of not just his hand, but entire body causes worry. Every pivot of his neck even remotely in your direction causes you to hold your breath. Even the gentle drags of fabric over your body makes you erk and make the grip on your musket even more vice-like. The irresponsibility loud orders from the man finally radiate out and engulf your ears. The language is completely exotic to you... they must be French. You grit your teeth and dig your heels into the coarse yet unstable dirt. The metallic jingle causes by the restless steeds quiet to make way for your thoughts. Your thinking slows down, but you need to make a decision, quick. Playing out every plausible event, you decide to: 1Ô∏è‚É£Take a shot whilst you still have the element of surprise. 2Ô∏è‚É£Gather as much info as possible, so that you can warn your allies. 3Ô∏è‚É£Take the chance to run as you surely can‚Äôt win such a hopeless battle. Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 1/27/2021 10:32 AM
Although forced to compete against a language barrier, you try to make sense of the horseman‚Äôs actions. A sweep of the hand here, the odd point, provides enough information. You can understand a steady flow of plans, like a fruit‚Äôs peel squashed for every last drop of juices. Although the painfully obvious gestures sufficed in telling you where they were looking, the ordained clothing reflecting some light sure made it a lot easier. This observation made you think of your hat, black as a Frenchman‚Äôs heart, and it‚Äôs humble decor. You moved towards it and grimaced as you turned it backward with a low ruffle. Keeping your eyes fixed in the cavalry, one of them, seemingly bored or restless, glanced in your direction. As he passed, however, you began letting out a long heavy sigh. Yet this was quickly interrupted by the enemy‚Äôs double-take. He was surely squinting at you through the darkness, you too frozen to even glance upwards. After what felt like minutes, he turned to his officer and murmured something. Had he figured out you were right there staring back at him from the abyss? The superior, most likely unamused, shifted his focus toward your glowing camp. You followed suit, although you made sure to ready your gun, just in case, wincing the whole time. Surprised at how you managed to miss the now brightly shining camp, you theorised about what had happened. Had the French completely overrun the camp and lighted it ablaze, roasting anyone miraculously still asleep? It certainly seems like something they would do. As much as you tried to fight it, the view was too gorgeous. Far beyond anything a working man such as yourself would‚Äôve ever been lucky enough to see, the flames pushed out and were shortly forced back. Like an aggressive, hellish tide relentlessly clawing at anything adjacent. Pillars of embers and ash rose into the sky before gracefully fluttering to the earth. (continue below) (edited)
10:33 AM
They either let out a silent gasp and disappeared as quickly as they had come or gathered in a hopeless bid to rid the world of all things green. Witnessing it, it was hard to believe that ambition was hopeless. You gasp with each flare-up and conclude the floating materials look as if they were shot from canons aimed at the stars. The noiseless descents made you recall the brilliant tales of hot air balloons. That is surely how they must look gently landing. Various coloured smoke danced the dance of death, distorting and coalescing as demons saw fit. A Relatively calming sight changes at the speed of shot as what had to be a powder keg illuminated the Earth brighter than the summer sun. Immediately following, chunks of only God knows what rocketed into the sky accompanied by ear bursting cracks and pops. It was as if every exotic deity had come to a final confrontation above a sad forgotten hill. They brought their ghoulish banshees and fearless archers, firing flame covered arrows. Chunks disintegrated, came down and ended with shows brilliant enough to be clashes of demigods, or flew off to reunite with their mistress, the Moon. Your amazement tapering off, you stare back at the no longer dismissed warband. They stood, or rather sat, in complete astonishment. Not even hardened veterans could ignore such a sight. Every wrinkle in the commanding man‚Äôs face became visible, telling their own story of patriotic deeds and repressed losses. A wail erupted from somewhere deep in the ranks. Within an instant, a hand soothed a bloodthirsty sabre. With a mighty warcry and tsunami of neighs, dust flew up around them. You were certain they had seen you in the light and were coming to satisfy their bloodlust. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Cast your weapons to the inferno and hope all your beliefs about Frenchies are false. (Surrender like a sissy) 2Ô∏è‚É£ Book it for what remains of your hard built camp. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Thinking they will soon be upon you, take a shot as a last performance of defiance.

Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 2/2/2021 10:37 AM
Recoiling immediately like a hand placed in hot water, a yelp escapes your mouth. Whirling on a dime, your legs push you along whilst they ignore fatigue. The clanking of hoofs and fancy medals catch up to you as you near a few standing tents. An uneven patch of dirt catches your foot causing you to falter for just a second before fixing yourself. Your arms flail out in front of you, cringing as you realize the loss of valuable time. What sounds like an earthquake goes off in slow motion as the musket meets the ground violently. Skidding and turning back, you reach for the barrel as you glimpse a rider with a sword drawn. Focusing all your energy into your arm, you feel a change in texture and pull away. Musket in hand and feeling as if your body was just your wrist, you dive into a tent. Gasping for breath and yearning for rest you face the entrance. Through the elegantly waving flaps, you glimpse reddish light and fire to the side. Knowing you are trapped, you must make a move. Righting yourself, a galloping horse beautifully slows. Certain of the person‚Äôs identity you: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Aim for the entrance, sure to get a kill whilst sacrificing a value shot. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Ready your axe, hoping to deliver a swift deciding blow.
34
291
Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 2/10/2021 4:01 PM
Mimicking the ingrained posture of preparing to fell a tree, you ready your axe. Concentrating on the quiet sounds, chirping of insects surprisingly still present was all you could hear besides your ragged breathing. Concerned sounding French broke the practically silent environment like a whip. Unknowingly to you, a man with sparkling ornaments brandished a blazing torch. Crunching dry grass signalled an encroaching man, and your arms tensed in anticipation. Closer and closer the sounds came, every step seeming like the last. Simulating every possible encounter your confidence is bolstered. The treading ceases meaning he is right outside. Swiftly an obviously glossy blade pokes into the corner opposite you. Startled, you fumble with the axe before taking a step forward and crookedly swing it. Waiting for the satisfying feel of slight resistance before pushing through, you fret. Perceiving this with intense relief, your leg pushes into the ground and you pull while twisting. Gritting your teeth for just a second, the head dislodges. You almost lose control over the weapon due to the sudden change in velocity. Heat suddenly rushes over you and you think it is due to the heinous act you committed. This way of thinking is shattered, however, due to a plume of blackened smoke engulfing the exit. Thinking fast, you move towards the back of your newly formed prison. Diverting your eyes from the blood-caked edge, you hack at the corner. Warmth creeping towards you at a modest pace, you work as fast as possible. A rush of air fans the fire behind you, signalling a sizeable hole. Dropping your axe, your fingers dig at the edges of the hole. Shoving your musket first, you crawl as low as possible through the opening as flames lick your boots. Two French lay before you, although no details can be made out until your eyes readjust to the dark. One appears to be reloading and the other brandishes a sabre before him.
4:01 PM
1Ô∏è‚É£ Points towards the one reloading, hoping to deny him use of such a powerful tool. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Points towards the blade wielding one, hoping to stop a possible charge.
331
71
Maximiana (@coolwomanforever1) 3/2/2021 1:57 PM
Teasing the trigger, your breath draws to a close. Pausing for a second, a thunderous crack rips through the serene murmur of flames. A flicker of light bubbles next to your face, soot and smoke billowing out. Light pours out the barrel, carrying with it more various materials, and lingers in your vision. The now corpse of a reloading Frenchman crumples and slouches over with a gentle thud. Feeling for the hand axe behind you, you try and watch the other man despite the crippling dark and glow still enduring in your sight. Pulling up the axe in parallel with your legs, a hand axe is handled in front of you. Within instants, the man is upon you, waving a sabre like the body of a snake. The first strike is a clear miss, but your weapon not made for stabbing can't reach. Reluctantly you wait for a second attack and prepare an overhead swing. The enemy side steps and plunges fangs into your exposed squishy side. The pleased blade slides out effortlessly, as your body plunges towards the ground. Sorrow fills your defeated mind, knowing you have been outsmarted and out-skilled. Blazing disdain grows behind your emptying eyes and he closes his. Mouth corners faltering, his arm rises to the sky. With a reluctant sigh not giving you enough time to even pray, a final slash digs into your torso. A thought confirming your views on the French fills your mind and a regretful face fills your vision. Light fleeting and darkness gaining, a single tear marks the transition to black, not giving you enough time to forgive the young soul. Gloom and tranquillity mark the beginning of something new; your epic excursion through the next realm...

May 10, 1805. 4:30PM "Lets wait for backup" said Clark, steadily, he stood up and went into the tent. I sat near the stool near the cannon, and waited. I might have drifted to sleep when a boom woke me up. I couldn't figure out what was going on when. Grapeshot and round-shots rained down on the camp! "WE'RE BEING FIRED ON, THE ENEMY ARTY KNOWS OUR LOCATION"! Clark yelled as he pulled me inside the reinforced tents. SPOSHHH! "ARGH"! I screamed in agony as I was hit in one of my legs. Blood sprout out from my legs and formed a pool of blood. "DANG IT FREEMEN, WE NEED A MEDIC HERE"! What medic? There was no medic, only 1000 Prussian soldiers were sent in, the French outnumber is 3 to 1. We were the only ones left in our camp. Clark opened our only medkit and found some bandages. He patched up my leg. It became instantly red. "We can't stay here anymore, we have to move. Lets move while they are reloading. What do you think, Johnson"? I thought to myself. 1Ô∏è‚É£Let's move, we aren't gonna survive staying here. There must be a medical station somewhere here. 2Ô∏è‚É£Let's stay and fire back, die with glory! QUICK! THIS POLL WILL ONLY BE UP FOR 5 MINUTES, CHOOSE THIS QUICK TIME EVENT STAT! @Text Story HURRY! (edited)

Charging inside would be a death wish.‚Äù ‚ÄúYea, we aren‚Äôt going to help much if half of us die before even reaching the base.‚Äù I thought about this for a second, and one soldier, Borus, came up to me and said, ‚ÄúSir, I know a town here called La Rothiere, it‚Äôs not far from here and has a radio, we can call your Russian friends and form up a plan.‚Äù The rest of the soldiers agreed, and we rode to the town. ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ La Rothiere, 7 hours before the battle of the Frozen Forest. ‚ÄúHere we are, La Rothiere.‚Äù I said to my soldiers. The town seemed deserted after news about the war broke out. But there were still a few left dusting the church and keeping things in order. I talked with some locals while our radio operator tried to communicate with our main base. It was nice talking about life other than war. Been a while. ‚ÄúSir, I‚Äôm getting nothing from your friends. Maybe they were‚Ä¶‚Äù before the radio operator could finish, I shushed him and told him to keep trying. They were alive, they had to be. The road to the forest, 3 hours before the battle of the Frozen Forest. ‚ÄúAny news on that radio?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúNo sir, still nothing.‚Äù The operator replied. The road to the forest, 2 hours before the battle of the Frozen Forest. Btzzzz-- Crackle--- Betzzzz--- Static-- ‚ÄúHello? Who is this?‚Äù A voice from the radio asked. ---Btzzzz
9:23 AM
‚ÄúWe are a small group of soldiers ready to assist you in the upcoming invasion.‚Äù Said the operator. ‚ÄúInvasion? What invasion? You must be out of your mind. 9:24 AM
Russian main base. The Battle of the Frozen Forest. As more and more Russian soldiers were picked off by French sharpshooters, hope began to fade in the camp. All the cannon crew was dead, and the French had begun to use the cannons as their own. Showering the Russians with deadly grape shots. GiantSquad watched as a little boy next to him had his head blasted off by a bullet. Blood dripped all over him, he prayed and fired his gun. ‚ÄúWhere is God when you need him?‚Äù He prayed, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let us die, my lord, please.‚Äù After 10 minutes, only 100 more Russian soldiers remained, some ducked behind a tent, they were soon penetrated by graph shots. Those hiding behind the hay were met with the same outcome. Giant and the remaining men hid behind some sapper barricades, those round shots shredding the wood to splinters. The cover was running out, more and more men fell to the ground, screams of the French surrounded the men. The sap who was building with his life has died to a rifleman. It was over. When they were ready to charge, the yelling of the French stopped as the buglers charged at them. ‚ÄúWhat the, IT‚ÄôS REINFORCEMENTS.‚Äù The commander cried out loud. The French panicked as the sudden waves of cavalry rushed them. However, the horses didn‚Äôt last long as they were brought down by grape shots. However, the Russian forces had tripled its size and are now half the size of the French. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up Giant,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúGood to see you, my friend, I knew you weren‚Äôt against us.‚Äù He replied. Shot his gun and ended the life of an artillery officer. Sounds of music were heard, the French were playing ‚Äúla charge‚Äù. The French made one last charge, sappers with axes the size of muskets were charging at the base. Breaking everything to allow more and more allies to charge in. ‚ÄúDANG IT, WHAT DO WE DO?‚Äù Giant asked.
9:24 AM
1Ô∏è‚É£ Stay and make the final stand. (Chances: survive the French charge, and win the battle. / this action will lead to a similar faith of ‚ÄúCuster‚Äôs last stand‚Äù.) 2Ô∏è‚É£ Chargeback at the French, using everything you got to counterattack. (Chances: Overpower the French‚Äôs rush, overwhelm the rest of the troops, win the battle. / this action will be vice versa against you. Your troops will be overwhelmed and slayed during the battle. This is the final choice, if you pick wrong, you die, if you pick right, you live. You might want to discuss this with your peers or dm me for hints. (edited)

The Most Reverend fuzzball525 7/31/2021 10:17 AM
I jolt awake, covered in sweat. I sit up in bed, breathing heavily. Suddenly, my wife stirs. "Dear, did you have that dream again?" she asks me. "Yes..." I answer back. "Again" she says. I've been having dreams like this since I left the damned army. "Oh dear, you simply must get these thoughts out of your head. I'm sorry but I need to sleep." "Darling, I don't mean to upset you. I just don't know how to get them out of my head." "Maybe talking about it would help? Just tell me all about these dreams." She lays a hand on my face and kisses my cheek. "Go on, tell me everything." I breathe in and out several times. My gaze is drawn to a czapka sitting on the nearby dresser. Faded, but still of fine quality, it taunts me nightly. "It was at Raszyn..." -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The stirring of men to the reveille, the shuffling and snorting of horses and the hammers of the weapon smiths fills the camp. Today is the day the Austrians will attack. I put on my uniform and sharpen my lance and sword. I give my horse a pet on the mane before mounting her and riding out of camp. Other men soon join me, including my dear friend Tuzsolski. "Morning Tuz," I say, using the nickname I'd thought of for him. "Same to you Wisi," he replies, smiling. He was a tall man for a cavalryman, of fairly stout build, blue eyes, and a fine mustache waxed at the ends (per regulation). "I suppose today is the day we fight," I say, trying to appear happy but secretly afraid, even after a few months. "You and I will both be fine. We'll kick the Austrians all the way back to Vienna!" He flourishes his lance to make a point. Suddenly our commander rides out in front of us. "Alright troopers, today you will show your mettle. I need you to..." 1Ô∏è‚É£ "Flank the Austrians to distract them." 2Ô∏è‚É£ "Do a frontal charge." @Text Story
149
22
The Most Reverend fuzzball525 8/1/2021 10:33 AM
"I need you to flank the Austrians, to distract them from the infantry's main attack. God be with you men. Now do your duty!" our commander tells us. We let out a loud cheer and begin riding to attack the Austrian right flank, which rests on some woods. We had hoped to rely on the element of surprise, but suddenly... CRACK a shot rattles the air! A cavalryman falls. I look up. An Austrian jager, probably posted as a sentry, has spotted our maneuver and fired a warning shot! It won't be long before he gets reinforcements! Thinking quickly, I look at Tuzsolski, and he nods. We couch our lances and charge down the jager, spearing him in seconds. But we were too late. Already I see at least a dozen men in white coats marching towards the sound of the shot. Our comrades join us, let out a battle cry and charge into the men before they can properly form up. The cries of men and horses, the clashing of swords and bayonets and lances, and the thump of bodies as they hit the ground fill the air. We kill Austrians but more appear. We can't hold them back forever. Have we done enough? YES! The crack of musket fire reaches my ears. The infantry have reached the center of the Austrian line! Our distraction was successful. Sensing this and hoping to preserve some of our lives, our bugler sounds the retreat. As we ride away, I turn around and see... TUSZOLSKI! He's pinned beneath his horse with Austrian soldiers approaching. What should I do?? 1Ô∏è‚É£ Ride in quickly and save him. Every man is needed to repel this attack. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Leave him there and ride off with your regiment. He may be your friend but it's simply too late for him. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Ride off, get some help and hope the Austrians are humane enough to capture him instead of kill him. @Text Story

The Most Reverend fuzzball525 8/2/2021 10:22 AM
"Tuz, I'm coming!" I rear up my horse and charge straight for him. One of the Austrians spots me and shoots my czapka off my head. I don't falter. I continue moving forward. Another Austrian soldier panics and... and... -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Tears fill my eyes as I pause in my storytelling. My wife embraces me. "It's alright, dear. Take your time..." I hug her back and straighten myself out. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ...and thrusts his bayonet straight into Tuszolski's chest. His cry of pain barely reaches my ears with the amount of pure rage I feel. I dismount my horse, pull out my sabre and slash one Austrian in the shoulder. He falls to the ground. The other Austrians panic and retreat. "Wisi, you crazy bastard... why'd you come for me?" Tuszolski says between labored breaths. "I'd never leave you behind." I reply. "Just stay with me! We can get you to an aid station!" "It's too late for me. Just go. Kill every last Austrian in this town before you retrieve my body." With that, he slips off into death's embrace. I cannot cry. I can only store my rage deep within my heart. I rejoin my comrades to await further orders. We can hear the sounds of combat in the town from our camp. While we wait for our next task, I make up my mind. I dismount my horse, grab a pistol, and begin making my way to the town. There must be something more I can do to make this battle go faster. I must not break my promise to Tuz! I reach the first few houses in Falenty and begin sneaking around, hoping to strike a damn good blow against the Austrians.
10:26 AM
I find the church and decide to climb up to the steeple to get a lay of the land. As I make my way to the church door, I notice a man in a white uniform and a bicorne ride by. He is followed by several hussars. A general... I think to myself. Looking up to the steeple, I see several Austrian soldiers up there. They're probably using it as an artillery spotting station. Which should I take care of first? 1Ô∏è‚É£ Climb up to the steeple and take care of the Austrians up there to cripple their artillery strength. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Try to track down the general and kill him. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Keep searching the town and see what else you can find. @Text Story

The Most Reverend fuzzball525 8/3/2021 9:41 PM
I follow the mounted man in white. I hide behind a house and hear his horse's hooves come to a halt. I peer around the corner and see the general. He has his back to me and is talking to one of the hussars. If only I could get him alone somehow... Just then, as if some unseen power above was listening, the hussars ride away. It seems he was telling them to deliver a message. I creep out from behind the corner, sword and pistol at the ready. As I approach, he startles and turns around. There is no time to wait! I charge him with the sword ready, but I'm too slow. He pulls out his own blade and blocks my swing. We spar for a moment, but then he pulls out a pistol and blasts me in the foot. "DAMN IT!" I cry. I collapse to the ground holding my wounded foot. He points his blade at my throat. "Du kommst mit mir, Pole." he says. His guards arrive and take me to the Austrian camp. Before I know what's happening, a doctor in a bloodstained coat is bandaging my foot. "What will happen to me?" I ask him. "The Austrians tend to keep prisoners for a long time." he answers in heavily-accented Polish. "You are Polish?" I wonder aloud. "Yes, I am. My father was an Austrian public official, so I had no choice but to join the Austrian ranks." I am about to ask him something else when a soldier arrives. "Aufstehen." he orders. I follow him to a tent filled with crates. He shoves me in and closes the flaps. I can see his silhouette through it. What do I do now? I wonder to myself... 1Ô∏è‚É£ Bust out right now. The Austrian has his back to you. You can rush him and catch him off guard. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Wait for a while. Perhaps your comrades will reach the camp and rescue you. Maybe something else will happen. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Try and cut an escape route through the back of the tent. If you're quiet you can make it. There's probably something in this tent to cut your way out with. @Text Story

Deleted User 8/14/2021 10:21 PM
You decided to sleep in the woods and move until daylight shines. "I guess I'll sleep." I said tiredly, today was a tiring a day, always hiding from the soldiers and finally made it out of the camp. I found a spot under a tree, and used my jacket as a blanket. I was beginning to drift into sleep before hearing a bunch of animal howls. I've been surrounded by a bunch of wolfs! "HEY!" I yelled, "STAY BACK, I DON'T WANT TROUBLE!" As if the wolfs could understand me, they got into attack formation and was growling at me. I raised my sword and soon was ready to fight. One wolf approached me, jumping at me and taking a bite of my leg, As I yelped in pain I sliced the wolf, ending its life. There was still so many more, there is no way I could take them down all by myself. I opened a sack and found a flint and steel. I collided the two together and made some sparks, that was enough to scared the wolfs for a few second. I took my chance and ran. The wolfs followed me as I kept running, I managed to dodge one's attack and kill it. There was still a ton left. Just as I was getting tired, I saw something up ahead. It was a town, a town and the end of the woods. With the remaining strength I had, I ran into a house. The wolfs didn't follow me. I rested and went to get familiar with my surroundings. It was a small town and most people were sleeping, some was on the streets selling food. The sack I got had a few coins and some ammo inside. I used those money to buy some bread and soup. It was the best meal I've every had in a while. Always eating those disgusting military meals. I made myself a bed out of hays and slept, no more wild animals attacking me now. The next day. I got up at the first hint of daylight, there was already commotions on the streets, people in wagons are going to work as paperboys and people opening their shops filled the streets. I was still wearing my war outfit, so people always stared at me, murmuring things under their breaths. I used the remaining money I had to buy some more food and a gun from the blacksmith, I was also able to get a horse from a stable and rode off. I have no idea where my allies are. Was the war over? Did we win? What do I do? 1Ô∏è‚É£Stay in the town, it's a good income of resources, maybe I should find some work to do and earn money. 2Ô∏è‚É£Ride off and try to locate your allies, if you had anymore left. 3Ô∏è‚É£Ask the people in town if they've seen any soldiers nearby, and follow the information you get. You've decided to ride off and try to locate your allies. Lets see how you do. It was noon, the air was just right, but the sound of the battle was never tiring. A fog was starting to form. You've decided to sneak in the woods and take out the enemies rambo style. "Hmmp". I moved quickly as I sneaked my way into the woods, ducking and crouching to get out of LOS. I spotted a young Austrian soldier getting left behind because of his heavy equipment, I approached him and grabbed him by his back. I put my sword to his throat and sliced. Blood poured out from his neck, he was dead instantly. I took some of his ammo and his knife, and continued to move. As I scouted the forest, all the other enemies were in packs, some moved in duos, trios, and more. It was going to be hard taking them all out. I do have a musket and a pistol, so I decided I was going to use them. I took aim at an ranker's head, and fired. The ranker jolted forward as the bullet penetrated his head, the rest of the soldiers were now alerted. I hid behind the trees and began to reload my musket. The soldiers were now looking for me, and I was ready. Just as a Austrian ranker approached me, I raised my pistol and shot point blank at his chest, the firepower caused him to fly backwards, hitting a tree and stopping, dead. More soldiers are now educated of my existence, I aimed my musket and took out another soldier, he cried out in pain and fell to the ground. I ran. Deleted User 9/6/2021 11:41 AM
You chose to get inside your base. Let's see how it plays out. I left the campfire, it was not worth engaging due to the number of people. It was getting really dark, the moon was hanging above me as crickets chirped in the bushes. I took a look at my base, the lights were on and soldiers were patrolling the camp. I took advantage of the darkness and walked up to the gate, soldiers pointed their guns at me. "Halt, who are you?" One asked. He pointed his gun, ready to fire. "HOLD!" I yelled, "I am private Wisizi from commander Toppo's 17 regiments, I have gotten lost but I found my way back." The gate was opened and commander Toppo rushed to me. "WISIZI!" He cried, "How are you my friend, I heard that they captured you. We sent men outside looking for you day and night. So glad for you to be back." Right before I was about to talk, he dragged me into a tent and went over the plans for tomorrow's warfare. "Take a look, we need the cavalry to charge, distracting the Austrians as our main force attacks from the woods." He said. "You will have to be brave, I am now making you a captain, you will charge alongside 20 other men, good luck tomorrow." He told me to get some sleep as tomorrow is the day that might determine the winner of this war. I was ready. @Text Story

107
Deleted User 9/10/2021 4:19 PM
TOO TOOOOOOOO The sound of a bugle being played filled my ears, within a matter of seconds, the whole camp was awake. With satisfaction, the bugle boy gave everyone a smirk and ran off, fearing getting beat up. "WHAT IS IT, IT'S ONLY 4 AM!" Said, one grumpy soldier. "I DIDN'T SIGN.." Before he could finish, the commander showed himself, and he quickly silenced his mouth. "Men, today is the day, you brave souls shall crush the enemy." He said, with determination. We quickly got dressed in our uniform and went into the barn to retrieve our gear and horses, within 15 minutes, we were all mounted and ready. The commander gave me a nod and went to check on the main infantry forces. A soldier opened the gate and we started to ride. I felt the excitement of this attack, riding with my comrades, and the feeling of destroying the enemy made me feel even better. I was ready for anything, we cannot lose this. Passing around the town, we saw the Austrian camp, there was already cannon fire at us, those field guns are more deadly than ever. BOOM! Grapeshots came flying at us, some horses went down, along with their rider. But this was no time for remorse. "ATTACK!" I yelled. We charged into the base and the Austrians were soon everywhere, soldiers were out of ranks and chaos was starting to form. The cannon crews fled and the sappers lost their hammers, screams and blood were everywhere, this rush was successful. Just as I felt that this day couldn't get any better. There was a sudden scream of Polish as soldiers appeared out of the woods and the town, bayonets ready as cannonballs bombed the Austrian camp. This was it, we've done it. The Austrians knew that it was over, they dropped their guns and a flag bearer raised a white flag, we've won. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 30 minutes later, we were all lined up, the enemy commander gave our commander his sword, they surrendered, and we won. The battle of Falenty is now over. We were victorious. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- "Wow hon, that was some battle." My wife said, "Can't believe that ending, sounds like real fun." I smiled, I finally stopped fearing that war. It was already 7 am, I got up and went to get some coffee. @Text Story End. gg ez no re.

45
Deleted User 9/23/2021 8:45 PM
Parker Summer, 1809, Halberstadt Park felt a breeze blowing on his face, the air has always been so calm and nice, as it's always been. He was a commanding officer of the 5th Infantry Regiment, a role fit only for the experienced, his men were well trained, they were ready for anything. I mean, they've had musket reloading contests, his squad always came out on top. Oh, and there was target practice, his squad was the only one hitting over 15 targets. "Sir, requesting permission to take a dump, on your head!" Jackson yelled, one of the best soldiers in the squad, he took down 3 Brunswich men all by himself, impressive. All the rest of the men laughed, Parker sighed, his men were elite, but nothing is stopping them when comedy infects them. Parker's order was to patrol the outskirts of Halberstadt, which he and his men were doing for the past 6 days, nothing exciting was happening, and he and his men were bored out of their minds. They had news that the Brunswick will plan an invasion soon, but they don't know exactly when. Soldiers are getting paranoid of spies in the camp and so on, but Parker paid no direct attention to them. He did listen to them, however, he's been keeping an eye on suspicious people around the camp, for example, Nike. Nike was a new soldier introduced to the army, he says he was a school teacher in France, or so does he claim. Parker has been keeping an eye on Nike, as new soldiers tend to be arriving spies. "SIR! WE'VE GOT MOVEMENT!" Parker turned around and saw figures walking through the forest surrounding the town. (I'm assuming that there is a forest, correct me if I'm wrong.) He forgot his spyglass at the camp, so he couldn't make out one. Were they Brunswick soldiers? Were they attacking? Or were they just some hunters taking a stroll? He doesn't know. "Parker, what do we do?" It was an old soldier, he goes by the name Santiago, and was said to be the best shot of the entire squad. He saved Parker a long way back, they were good friends. Parker didn't know what to do, he can send his squad in to investigate, what if it's just some hunters? Maybe they can trade some resources. Or what if it's the Brunswick scouts? Do they fight? What do you do? 1Ô∏è‚É£Advance and investigate, send one member of your squad to report back to camp. 2Ô∏è‚É£Stay and watch their movements, send one member of your squad to report back to camp. 3Ô∏è‚É£Shoot at the men and stay where you are, you might hit a few, send one member of your squad to report back to camp. 4Ô∏è‚É£Keep patrolling, pretend nothing has happened. @Text Story I'm back, will be updating frequently.

Deleted User 10/1/2021 9:25 PM
So it seems, you would like to trade with the hunters. Lets see what happens next. Parker approached the men, who were all busy hanging up their loot on their horses and getting ready to go. "Hey!" Parker yelled, the attention of the hunters turned to him. "Whatsup? Little Soldier?" One of the older hunter asked, he took off his hat and studied Parker. "Looks like you got some hunting loot?" Parker said, "We've got some fine army stuff, we can trade." This intrigued the hunters. Here are what you can get. 3 of your military muskets for the hunters's hunting muskets. The hunting muskets are far more effective than the standards at close range, and feature a special barrel that shoots multiple musketballs. (Blunderbuss prototype.) 100 Westphalian franks for the hunters' reinforced hunting cloaks. This special cloak can withstand standard musketballs. 50 Westphalian franks for a spyglass. Used to spot enemies at long range. You have around 500 Westphalian franks.

8:45 PM
Noland ‚ÄúThe Battle of Halberstadt? Boy that was a good one, I‚Äôll tell yer about it, but yer won‚Äôt believe it, I swear to ye. Ain‚Äôt nothing better than ma time in Halberstadt, that city, I‚Äôll never forget it.‚Äù Noland was an old man in his 70s, with a raspy voice and a tired-looking body, he says he was one of the veterans during the battle, but most people won‚Äôt believe him; his stories were just too crazy. Summer, 1809, Halberstadt ‚ÄúGiddy up men, carry those wood and follow me! Today we are going to fortify the west side of the city, the commanders want us to build really good, no slacking today!‚Äù A young man in his 30s spoke up, don‚Äôt get fooled by his voice, he is actually a strong man that experienced the worse. Noland was the son of a blacksmith and carpenter, he‚Äôs won building contests before and invented a prototype barricade. No one‚Äôs ever built anything better than Noland before. If you look across the road, there are tons of building materials for the sappers, they have to get as much work done as they can before the Brunswick attack. Noland and his men marched along the road, assigning sappers to places that needed fortification. The Kingdom of Westphalia was outnumbered by the Brunswick 1-3, there aren‚Äôt enough soldiers to guard 360 degrees of the city. After all the men are working on something, Noland found a low wall and began to work on it. The sun was high when he finished, the broken wall has been transformed into a military-grade fortification, talk about skills. Noland stood on top of the structure and looked out into the plains outside the city, some cows are grazing on the grass, and ducks were swimming in a nearby pond. Noland swung his vision to the right and looked at the forest, some wild squirrels climbing on the trees, some birds singing on the branches, some figures moving through the trees, some acorns... Wait, some figures moving through the trees? What the heck? Noland tightened his forehead and observed movements through the woods, could it be hunters just taking a stroll through the woods? Or is it, something else? What are you doing to do? 1Ô∏è‚É£Jump out the wall and investigate, you'll have your axe if anything goes bad. 2Ô∏è‚É£Report your findings back to a camp, you'll come back for it, if they are still there. 3Ô∏è‚É£Gather up your men and check it out together, strengh in numbers. 4Ô∏è‚É£Eh who cares, your job is only to build anyways. @Text Story

Deleted User 11/8/2021 6:07 PM
"Hey lads, I think we should group up!" Said Noland, as he grabbed his ax and looked closely at the movements. His men were light-speed, gathering around him in a matter of minutes. "What do you want man?" Said one of the workers impatiently, "I've got work to do and want to sleep, just tell me what happened." Noland told the sappers that he saw movements in the wood and was unsure of what it was coming from, all of them agreed to go out and take a look as a group. It was close to sunset as they all moved in the woods, searching for any signs of movement. After a while, most of the people were numb about the news and wanted to finish their work. Noland however, was sensing something sinister. "Hold up men, do you smell Brunswick cologne?" He said. "Brunswick cologne? Noland, what are you a Brunswick politician or something? How do you even know what Brunswick cologne smells like?" One of the sappers said. Noland started to question his eyesight, he was sure that he saw something, maybe it was just a fox or something, who knows. "Alright men, let's go back and finish what we started," Noland said, just as they turned around, one of the men screamed and fell to the ground, blood poured out from his chest, shots were being fired. "BRUNSWICK SOLDIERS!" Noland yelled, "FALL BACK MEN FALL BACK!" Sappers were running all over the place as shots came from almost everywhere, men dropped like flys, the remaining survivors either hid behind a tree or made it back to Halberstadt. "HOLY CRAP!" Yelled one of the sappers, "WHAT DO WE DO?" What do you do? 1Ô∏è‚É£You have an ax, your men have an ax, let's use our axes against the Brunswick. 2Ô∏è‚É£Keep falling back, you might lose more men in the process, but some will survive. 3Ô∏è‚É£Stay where you are and watch the Brunswick's movements, if they retreat, you live, if you attack, well, :(. 4Ô∏è‚É£Surrender and become prisoners. @Text Story My sincere apologies for the delay, had to do an huge essay.

Deleted User 12/2/2021 8:50 PM
Noland and his men all had axes, ‚ÄúLet's use our axes against the Brunswick!‚Äù Said Noland, in a loud voice, as they dashed behind a tree, avoiding enemy shots. ‚ÄúQuick! I need three groups all even except the ones who will rush them directly! One group rushes the left flank and the other group rushes the right flank, and the smallest group rushes them directly! Don't forget to stick by the trees, they are your only cover! ‚ÄùNoland yelled, trying to communicate with his comrades. Nolands men now quickly spread into groups without thinking much of it, as they were already being shot at and didn't have time to argue. Noland was glad he brought his comrades with him, so he never had to die alone, but forgot it as a bullet slammed into the tree he was behind. They began to flank, as they began to quickly lay down wood to extend their cover, they are sappers after all, as bullets flew by, and a man who was building a so-called barricade tumbled over, blood spilling across the grass, as his life then faded away in front of Nolands eyes. Noland‚Äôs friend, Bernard, yelled over at Norland ‚ÄúGet over here! Your cover is getting shredded to swiss cheese!‚Äù Norland had no choice, he had to run to the main cover being built a few meters away, but bullets would never stop, they just kept flying by, Noland feared getting hit by one of those, especially in the gut, where he would die a painful death. As the bullets seemed to cease now, and the sound of gunfire quit, Noland rushed over to the left cover now, as he slid right beside Bernard.
8:50 PM
‚ÄúThey are reloading!‚Äù A sapper called out, as he now rushed over to the right cover, eventually, they began to make progress, getting closer and closer to the Brunswick soldiers, sticking very close to the trees. Finally! Noland and his men finally got close enough where they were fighting hand to hand now. ‚ÄòSwoosh! C-Crack! ‚ÄòBang!‚Äô sounds of gunfire, swords, and axes filled the forest, as Bernard swung his ax at someone's throat now, sending him to the floor. Noland began to swing his ax all around, he didn‚Äôt care if he got one, he just wanted to get out of this. Both sides lost quite a lot of men. Noland now swung his ax over to an Officer's skull, blood splattering all over Noland‚Äôs uniform, but then he heard it. ‚ÄòKi-Crack!‚Äô ‚ÄòBoom!‚Äô Two guns have fired, as Noland glanced around the forest, seeing who would fall from musket fire, two of Noland‚Äôs best builders have fallen, blood gushing from their chest A Brunswick soldier now ran towards Noland, as he had his bayonet pointed towards Noland‚Äôs heart. Noland stopped now, as he reckoned this was the end, but then an ax fell towards the Brunswick soldier, over to his temple, as the soldier fell dead, just a few meters away from Noland. It was Bernard, Bernard had just saved Noland‚Äôs life! Eventually, the Brunswick soldiers made a retreat, as they had a lot of wounded or dead. Noland reckoned they should do the same, as they also had many casualties on their side. But then, ‚ÄòKi-Crack!‚Äô A bullet swooshed by, landing right in Bernard‚Äôs left lung. Bernard held onto his wound, as he began to choke, blood running out of his chest, and managed to leak through his hands, as Bernard now fell to the floor. After this, a line of flesh tearing musket balls flew by now, as at least nine-12 soldiers collapsed. Seems the battle isn't over, maybe reinforcements? Maybe an illusion? Maybe they wanted to trick us into believing they were retreating, and then round themselves back and fire at us
8:51 PM
New Objective: Don't Die. 1Ô∏è‚É£ : Runaway, get your men and run, or just run away by yourself if you get your comrades to come. 2Ô∏è‚É£ : Fight, use your axes again, you don't know if they are reinforcements or not, but it's worth a shot. 3Ô∏è‚É£: Take cover behind the trees, same exact tactic. 4Ô∏è‚É£ : Surrender, it may not be too late? 5Ô∏è‚É£: Well... Deleted User 1/1/2022 5:23 AM
You have chosen to follow the group headed towards the frozen river. You swerve your horse to the left and catch up with the pair of hussars and dragoons. From a distance, you see a few enemy horsebacks attempting to flank your base. You put your bugle down and draw your sabre, ready to attack. Your teammates do the same. The French cavalrymen notice your presence and direct their attention towards you. [kevinchad444]: A l'attaque! [kevinchad444]: Ecrasez les! [Vault_73]: justin poop his pans [Team] [24dasr]: cHarge! You hold your sabre up high as you get closer to an Austrian lancer. You swing it as hard as you can, but the lancer manages to dodge it at the last second. Just as you're about to turn your horse around, a hussar comes crashing into you from your right. Both of you fall off your horses and onto the icy ground. You almost land on your own blade. You try to recover, however the enemy hussar gets up and attempts to stab you in the chest. You kick the sabre out of his hands just in time. He pounces on you before you can get up and lands a punch on your left shoulder. You return the favor by pressing your thumbs into his eye sockets, neutralizing him. As he tries to pull your thumbs away, you wrap your fingers around his head and push him to the side. You start punching him in the head repeatedly before reaching out for your sabre. The hussar manages to pull your arm away from it. You try to escape his grip but it's too strong. He also has his right foot on your other hand. You struggle to wrestle your way out from his hold as he reaches for your blade instead. What will you do? 1Ô∏è‚É£ Headbutt him [It wouldn't do good to your head, but it seems like a surefire way to stop him.] 2Ô∏è‚É£ Knee him in the crotch [Eh, I doubt he'll see his wife again anyways.] 3Ô∏è‚É£ Roll your body to the opposite side [You're basically pulling him away from the sabre.] 4Ô∏è‚É£ Try to distract him [Maybe he'll let go of your arm if you confuse him...]

@Text Story
Deleted User 1/3/2022 8:37 AM
You have chosen to knee the hussar in the crotch. His face quickly turns a bright red. He lets go of your arms, giving you a chance to reach for your sabre. You attempt to finish the job, however the hussar gets trampled by one of the horses, stomping his face into a bloody pulp. You almost puke from the horrifying sight. You hurry back to your horse. It was struggling to get back to its feet, so you try to help it up. Unfortunately, one of your horseback teammates trips over your fallen horse. You manage to dodge the impact, however you start hearing a strange cracking noise. Before you can figure out what it is, the ice below you breaks, sending you into the freezing cold water. You frantically try to get to the surface, but the sudden change in temperature has sent your whole body into a state of shock. You watch as the hole becomes bigger in size. More and more horses drop into the river. You see the silhouettes of troops in the water. Their panicking can be heard faintly. No matter how hard you try, you just can't move your arms enough to swim back up. You have lost all your energy trying and realize that you have met your demise. You close your eyes and think about your loved ones as you slowly sink to your death... Everything is pitch black. Your surrounding is so quiet. You feel nothing at all. ... Then, you hear a voice. 1Ô∏è‚É£ "Wake up, comrade..." 2Ô∏è‚É£ "Honey...?" 3Ô∏è‚É£ "Awaken, my child..." @Text Story

billy big balls 1/19/2022 12:36 AM
You have been selected to become a ranker serving in the Pavlovskiy Grenaderskiy. May you serve Russia well. –î–∞ –∑–¥—Ä–∞–≤—Å—Ç–≤—É–µ—Ç –¶–∞—Ä—å! (Long live the Tsar!) A sudden boom goes off. You open your eyes, shielding them from the explosions going off around you. Then, someone tugs onto your woolen greatcoat. It is Kapitan Bocharov, urging you to fall into the ranks of what is left of your division. "Yefeytor Alexandrovitch, fall into position!" You stare at him questioningly, wondering if he is out of his mind. "Where's... where's our commanding officer?" you reply. "Dead! No matter now, the damn French have us surrounded. Fall into position I say!" he orders. You do so confusingly, still dazed at what situation you have been landed in. "Soldiers of his Imperial Majesty's Army! We stand here overwhelmed and cut down by these dastardly French. But no fear, for I have sent word to send the nearest force to our position to push them off our flanks!" he proudly exclaims. A cannonball zooms by his shoulder, striking countless of Russians in the front and second ranks. Kapitan Bocharov stares at the bodies unperturbed. He abruptly raised his sword and declared "FIX BAYONETS!" You begin to fix your bayonet onto your musket and hold it in a ready position. Kapitan Bocharov nods, then motions to the drummer-boy to begin playing the Pavlovskiy Grenadier March. The drums rattle on, and the ranks begin to surge onto the battlefield with every soldier declaring "God save the Tsar!" You look around while you march, fearing you have been sentenced to death voluntarily. Suddenly, you spot the remains of a sapper's fortification. You begin getting ideas into your head. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Resume march-charging into the fray with the rest of your comrades 2Ô∏è‚É£ Take cover behind the sapper's fortification 3Ô∏è‚É£ Drop your musket and desert. After all, why fight for this silly cause? @Text Story Pretty long if I do say so myself. Enjoy it thoroughly whilst you can.

billy big balls 1/20/2022 5:43 PM
You run behind the sapper's fortification after a round shot decimates another group of rankers. The line marches on without you knowing. "What a relief..." you say to yourself. Suddenly, you hear footsteps crunching on the snow. You prepare your musket at the ready. They come closer... closer... You raise your musket while taking cover, yelling "DON'T MOVE OR I'LL SHOOT YOUR BLOODY HEAD OFF!" The mysterious figure drops his musket in view. "Come forward!" you shout, unable to see the person clearly due to the smoke. The person steps forward, revealing himself to be a fellow ranker in the Grenadierskiy. He tears up seeing a fellow soldier still alive. "How glad I am to see you, god ble-" The sound of a cannonball whizzes by, hitting part of the fortification. "I thought we took care of the artillery with the so-called charge?!" you angrily tell him. "We did!" he replied. "Just not entirely." You shake your head. "You have a name?" "Kirill Borisovich." "Name's Budimir Alexandrovitch. What's the status of our unit?" Kirill responds tentatively, "I didn't see them after they charged into the first artillery position. Knew it was a death trap, so I had to retreat." You nod slightly.
5:45 PM
"There is one thing however, Budimir. I think we can manage to take out the remaining artillery if we regroup back here with the other survivors." Kirill added. You respond, "Listen Kirill. I had something else in mind whilst I was taking cover. We can go back to our original base to scrounge around and find some supplies. After we do that, we can scout behind the enemy lines. Or we can just stay here until the reinforcements come." Kirill takes a moment to think about the options."Well then Alexandrovitch, what do you think we should do?" 1Ô∏è‚É£ Concede to Kirill's idea and locate survivors to take out the remaining artillery 2Ô∏è‚É£ Remain under cover. Hopefully the reinforcements come soon... There's no point in going out to die, is there? 3Ô∏è‚É£ Convince him that your idea will work if executed properly @Text Story The plot is beginning to thicken. Thank you to @„ÄÜ Ayhan and @Alejandro (@remwind) for your ideas! Remember, feel free to always send out more, any help is appreciated. (edited)

13
16
billy big balls 1/22/2022 5:10 PM
You think momentarily about your options. Finally, you decide to listen to Kirill's plan. "Let's give your plan a shot. God bless us if we are destined to die from there," you proclaim. Kirill nods gratefully and picks up his musket. "On we go then!" You both gather whatever supplies there are in the fortification and march on through the snow. Minutes go by as you pass bloody bodies, carcasses of horses, and broken weapons strewn around. Then, shots are heard with some distinct yelling. "That must be the survivors!" Kirill yells. You both run as fast as you can after them. The scene comes into view, and you see a number of French soldiers harassing the survivors who are hiding behind trees and a cannon with shots flying over their heads. You slide behind the nearest tree, noticing 4 partisans, 3 wounded Grenaderskiy comrades, and 5 regulars from the Sofia Pehotniy. One of the wounded notice you both. "More survivors! All the better~" he weakly proclaims, coughing out blood. You speak to him, "How'd you manage to get out of the assault?" The wounded grenadier points behind you. You turn and stare in shock. It is Kapitan Bocharov berating the partisans behind the trees. "WHAT THE DEVIL DO YOU THINK YOU ALL ARE DOING YOU COMMON RABBLE? HAVE YOU NO GUTS TO RUSH AT THE ENEMY?!" You groan in frustration, muttering "The hell is he doing still alive..." You crawl over to his cover. "Yefeytor Alexandrovitch reporting," giving a sullen salute. "ALEXANDROVITCH! IN GOD'S NAME, I SHOULD PUT YOU UP TO A COURT-MARTIAL IF WE GET OUT OF THIS GODFORSAKEN BATTLE!" he bellows. "Sir, how about we focus on getting out alive then we can figure out my court-martial?" Kapitan Bocharov stares at you for a moment. "Yes, I believe you're right Alexandrovitch. Any ideas on how to get us out of here?"
5:16 PM
You stare at the French positions and turn back to the Kapitan. "Did you manage to take out their artillery?" "Only momentarily Yefeytor. Soon they're going to send their infantry after us." A shout of "VIVE LA FRANCE!" is heard, and heavy marching follows right after. "Guess that's them now," the Kapitan shrugs. You shake your head and head to Kirill. "Get every available man to man their weapon! We will not let them take us out!" Kirill nods for a moment but is hesitant. "Kirill, what's the matter?" "They have more numbers than us Alexandrovitch. How can we manage to take them out?" "By the grace of Russia Kirill. Let's get moving." Your rag-tag group takes positions and aims at the enemy, waiting until they're in sight. "MAKE READY!" you proclaim. The enemy marches closer, now in sight. You notice 20 men in total, including an officer, 2 flag bearers, a drummer and a fifer, and 15 line infantry. You scan over your choices whilst aiming your musket. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Take out the officer 2Ô∏è‚É£ Direct fire towards the musicians and the flag-bearers 3Ô∏è‚É£ Coordinate a volley towards the line infantry 4Ô∏è‚É£ Pull back towards a relatively safer position @Text Story Sorry for the late delay, had some things to work on. Enjoy your first taste of combat, and try not to die. You all chose some very good choices lately!

billy big balls 1/23/2022 10:22 PM
"DIRECT SHOTS TOWARDS THE OFFICER!" you yell out. The regulars and the partisans take their aim and open fire. Much to your disbelief, they all manage to miss him. "Curses," you mutter. You turn to the Kapitan and notice he hasn't fired his pistol. You berate him for his inability to join in the fight. "ARE YOU REALLY SUCH A COWARD TO NOT SHOOT?! IT'S TOO LATE TO GIVE ORDERS NOW! OVER, D'YOU HEAR ME?!" The Kapitan looks dejected and gives out a small 'tsk.' He draws his pistol, takes his aim at the French officer, and fires the shot. The French officer stops for a moment. Blood flows out his temple, and he crumples to the ground. "Holy cow..." you all exclaim. The French infantry yells in disbelief and are unsure of what to do next. "SCARE THEM ALEXANDROVICH, ON WE GO! ON WE GO OLD CHUM!" Kirill yells, jumping over his cover whilst yelling ferociously. "After him! Don't let them go!" you yell, and the Kapitan assists you by urging the men on. You all rush after them with fixed bayonets, screaming at the top of your lungs, "FOR RUSSIA!" The French begin to pull back, and some infantrymen take the time to open fire on your advancing group. 2 Sofia Pehotniy conscripts are killed outright along with one partisan and two of them wounded. Still, it is not enough to slow down the rest who hack down the infantry lagging behind. You all take a moment to rest. "What's our next plan?" asks a partisan. "Well, we can't leave those dirty beggars to report stragglers!" exclaims Bocharov. "Kapitan, even if they were to report us, the reinforcements must be here by now, shouldn't they?" you ask. The Kapitan checks his watch. "Broken, damn it, but yes, at least 5 or so minutes, they should be here." You nod assuringly. "Good, then we mustn't waste our time on them." Kirill protests, "But Budimir, surely they don't have some means of support around the area? They might decimate us and surprise our reinforcements!" (edited)
10:26 PM
"We have no way of knowing that! Besides, we don't have the manpower to continue. Look at our casualties. I'm certain we can't attempt another surprise like that one!" you explain to Kirill. Kirill stays silent and fiddles with his musket. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Remain where you are for the reinforcements. They shouldn't be far at least... 2Ô∏è‚É£ Attempt to pursue the French infantry with the remaining manpower. @Text Story Boiling down to the final events of the story. Vote wisely, or death shall fall upon your group... and perhaps yourself.

billy big balls 1/27/2022 7:07 PM
"That's that then. We shall remain where we are and wait for our reinforcements." you proclaim. Everyone nods in agreement and rests in a spot, fixing their weapons and such. You check up on everyone to make sure they are prepared in case of another surprise attack. Minutes go by, and you all wait for the sound of marching or even horses. Kirill groans,"Budimir, I told you we should've gone after-" The sound of drums is heard, and the Russians all stand up cheering. "THEY'RE HERE! OUR BOYS ARE-" A shot is heard, and a bullet zips by, landing on Kirill's temple. He crumples to the ground, blood streaking on the snow. "SNIPERS! SNIPERS!" the Kapitan proclaims. Multiple shots ring out and strike him in the stomach. He too falls to the ground. The group is in alarm, clambering to their weapons. "LEAVE THEM!" you yell, "ORDERLY RETREAT TO OUR POST!" Everyone follows you as you try to retreat to where the post might have been located. More shots ring out, and one by one, soldier and partisan alike fall. You keep on running, not aware of what is going on behind you. Finally, you come to a stop near a snow-laden path. Voices are heard near you. You look around and notice everyone except you is gone. Tired to go on and realizing the enemy is near you, you lie down behind a tree hoping to conceal yourself. Something red drips on your pants. You try to wipe it off but are unable to. It is blood, coming out of the side of your stomach. Your eyes blur and start to close. "No... the reinforcements...." Silence.... @Text Story Suspenseful eh? The story doesn't end there... and this time, you have the complete power to change it (if you can.) Please pick either Option 1Ô∏è‚É£ or Option 2Ô∏è‚É£. The secret endings will be behind either one. (To make it not biased, I enlisted help from epic man.) Be considerate. (edited)

billy big balls 1/31/2022 6:16 AM
You have chosen... Option 2. You have... survived. A noise is heard crunching by your unconscious body. Two Russian Cossacks notice the blood leaking on the snow. They discover you and take you with them to the nearest field hospital, where you are duly treated. As soon as you regain consciousness, you inquire as to the fate of your comrades. "All dead Yefeytor. We got there as soon as we could..." You nod silently, tears slowly streaming down you. "If it hadn't been... for..." you trail off. The Cossack pats you sympathetically, you cannot help but wonder if any have made it in the Frozen Forest... of hell. @Text Story Yessirree indeed, we have finished our text story! billy big balls 2/5/2022 10:28 AM
Activating Die Hard Mode... activation complete. Beginning game. The Austrian soldiers mill around the church floor, cleaning their weaponry and watching for the Bavarians circling the Church. But under their very noses... a Bavarian is camped on the second floor. You assume the role of Offizier Bruce Aeigh, a seasoned fighter of the 4. Infanterie-Regiment who is trapped in the church which is heavily guarded and occupied by the enemy. You are cut off from your regiment, but if only there were a way to return back to them... You peek through a gap in the door, giving yourself a view of the Austrians below. "Hahn Grenadiers... tough bastards," you say in your head. You begin to check your equipment, which is two muskets, a pistol, a sabre, and a handle of an ax, all in good condition. Satisfied, you return to viewing the area below. The Grenadiers mill around unperturbed. Many are joking around, some are checking their equipment, and a few of them take the opportunity to get some shut-eye. Suddenly, the doors open, and an officer walks in, escorted by 4 of the Grenadiers. The Grenadiers all stand at attention, giving a salute. The officer promptly returns it. You try to get a better look at him but are unable to. "Good day Grenadiers. My name is Count von Maximilianerberhardtwilhelmusgoerlitzscheitzhaus. I am to be your commanding officer from this moment on. I shall finish the introductions another time, as we have to conduct a patrol along the town to scare off these bloody Bavarians. Pack up your equipment and move outside!" The Grenadiers respond with a hearty "Understood!" and begin to dress up. You notice this sudden activity and breathe a sigh. Soon, all but 5 Grenadiers are outside of the Church conducting the patrol. "Now is my time," you proclaim silently. Formulating a plan, you count 5 people, three of whom are rankers, one a sapper, and another one a musician.
10:34 AM
However, as you turn back to collect your weapons, you see a broken window. You look outside of it and notice you can climb up to the rooftop, giving yourself a bird's eye view of the surrounding area. Maybe you could even do some shooting if there was a battle. Bruce shakes his head, full of plausible ideas. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Eliminate the small group inside the Church. Maybe you could gain some more equipment and try something with the enemy's uniform... 2Ô∏è‚É£ Attempt to climb the Church roof so you can watch the enemy and even shoot them if busy. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Stay inside your hiding spot. Another chance may pop up if you wait long enough. @Text Story Alrighty! First text story decisions. Remember, this is Die Hard Mode, so anything wrong may happen if you're not careful.
140
32
12
billy big balls 2/7/2022 10:28 PM
Bruce thinks for a second and decides to eliminate the small group. The lesser the Grenadiers, the more chance he has to survive and regroup with his regiment to crush them. Turning around, he loads his weapons and looks over the targets. "Lots of choices..." he mutters. The rankers seem to have their guns stacked on the wall, with the musician and the sapper talking to each other. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Utilize silence to eliminate them one by one 2Ô∏è‚É£ Go in blasting loud and proud @Text Story This is gonna be a quick-pick choice, meaning after a certain amount of time (e.g 30 mins or 1 hour), we're gonna continue the story so as to get to the long and juicy parts.
113
11
billy big balls 2/8/2022 12:34 AM
You decide to take the undertaking silently and efficiently as possible. They seem to be off guard for the moment. As you decide your next step, you notice the handle of the ax on the ground. Picking it up, you clatter it around the floor, hoping to get some attention. You look outside the peek hole and notice the musician and the ranker looking around and walking your way. "Perfect." you smile, brandishing your sabre. Footsteps can be heard climbing the stairs, and you hide in a shadowy area. They approach near your spot while looking around. "You sure you heard something here?" spoke the musician. "Yes, you know it could have been anything Moritz..." replied his comrade. "Anything! Don't make me laugh, you'd think there was a Bavarian hiding here." retorted the musician. "You're right, you're right!" laughed the ranker. "He's damn right." you say as you plunge your sabre into the back of the musician. Blood would gush out of his stomach while he'd stare in shock at his comrade. Not waiting for any moment, you rush forward and stick the blade into the ranker as well, pushing him towards the wall. Both are dead after a few seconds. You'd remove the sabre from their bodies, wiping the blood off onto their uniforms. After moving the bodies to the corner, you would check on the three others down below. They'd be milling around doing their business. Feeling more bloodlust, you try to coax them to your spot by doing the same noise, but by yelling "OWCH!" That got their attention. The rest of the group walks up the stairs. What ensues next can be described as a work of art. Bodies strewn around, blood spatter on the floors, and what more? You are content with finishing the job.
12:35 AM
Now you start to plan out your next step to the plan. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Infiltrate the enemy with a Grenadier uniform 2Ô∏è‚É£ Lie in wait and see what plan you can do when the main force of Grenadiers return from their patrol 3Ô∏è‚É£ Do some silent reconnaissance around the town 4Ô∏è‚É£ Climb the roof onto the tower to do some sharp shooting @Text Story Lights, cameras, blood... that's the horror and gritty determination of the movie story...

billy big balls 2/10/2022 6:50 AM
You decide to climb the roof to snipe these cretins. Evaluating your ammunition and weaponry, you reload and prepare them for combat. After that, you start climbing the roof to make it onto the tower. Suddenly, your foot slips on a shingle that crashed onto the ground. "Damn. Be more careful Bruce..." you mutter. You reach the tower and hoist yourself into it, putting the weapons against one of the walls. Scoping the area with a musket, you soon catch sight of the enemy skirmishing with the Bavarians near the forest. You take aim for one of their Sergeants, who goes to outflank them with his party of Grenadiers. PFOOM! goes your musket. It strikes the Sergeant in his skull, sending pieces of his head flying onto his men's uniforms. They notice their dead Sergeant on the ground, yet they still march on with determination. "So that's how you bastards want to play the game, eh?" you sneer. Loading a musket, you fire another shot into one of their musicians who promptly falls dead. One by one the Grenadiers fall, their bodies twisting in the air and slumping on the ground with blood slowly pouring out of them. A pitiful sight, yet you know that war brings out the worst of everyone. You finish firing on the enemy. After making sure to reload your firearms, you look out into the battlefield. There lie many dead Grenadiers, wounded, and even a few who are still skirmishing behind the trees. Looking ahead of them, you notice the Bavarians slowly advancing onto their positions. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Finish off the remaining Grenadiers. It does no good to keep them alive, does it?... 2Ô∏è‚É£ Resume hiding in the Church. Surely their patrol must return after losing a staggering amount. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Exit the Church and explore the town to see if you can return to your Regiment safely. @Text Story Blood, blood, and more blood. There's a side to Bruce that has it's..... questionable moments.
